title: Moulding plane
text:
In <a href="woodworking">woodworking</a>, a moulding plane (molding plane in US spelling) is a specialised <a href="plane%20%28tool%29">plane</a> used for making the complex shapes found in wooden <a href="Molding%20%28decorative%29">mouldings</a>. 
Traditionally, moulding planes were blocks of wear resistant hardwood, often <a href="beech">beech</a> or <a href="maple">maple</a>, which were worked to the shape of the intended moulding. The blade, or <a href="iron%20%28plane%29">iron</a> was likewise formed to the intended moulding profile and secured in the body of the plane with a wooden wedge. A traditional <a href="cabinetmaker">cabinetmaker</a>s shop might have many, perhaps hundreds, of moulding planes for the full range of work to be performed. The late nineteenth century brought modern types which were all-metal affairs such as the American <a href="Stanley%20Works">Stanley</a> No. 55 Universal Plane and the English Record No. 405 <a href="Multi-Plane">Multi-Plane</a> with a wide variety of interchangeable cutters, integral fences, and "nickers", small cutting edges which score the grain fibers when working across the board.
Large <a href="crown%20moulding">crown moulding</a>s required planes of six or more inches in width, which demanded great strength to push and often had additional peg handles on the sides, allowing the craftsman's <a href="apprentice">apprentice</a> or other worker to pull the plane ahead of the master who guided it.
While generally considered outdated, a modern furniture shop doing reproduction or restoration work might keep a collection of moulding planes to match original work, or to build in an authentic manner.
The earliest known record of a moulding plane is a moulding plane iron of Roman origin unearthed in Cologne, Germany.
In modern industry, the work of the moulding plane has been taken up by the electrically powered spindle <a href="moulder">moulder</a> or <a href="wood%20shaper">wood shaper</a>. On a smaller scale, the hand-held or table-mounted electric <a href="Router%20%28woodworking%29">router</a> allows the use of interchangeable <a href="router%20bit">router bit</a>s of a wide variety of profiles and is readily available to the small business or home craftsperson.
